The set of uniformly hyperbolic cocycles is open in the -topology
(one allows perturbations both in  and in ).

Uniformly hyperbolic cocycles have a positive Lyapunov exponent.
If  has positive Lyapunov exponent but is not uniformly
hyperbolic then it will be called nonuniformly hyperbolic.

The advantage of defining reducibility "modulo " is to include some
special situations (notably certain uniformly hyperbolic cocycles).)

Given , let us consider the Schrodinger cocycle

( is called the potential and  is called the energy).

There is  fairly good comprehension of the dynamics of Schrodinger
cocycles in the case of either small or large potentials:

[Sorets-Spencer] Let  be a nonconstant potential, and let .  There exists  such that if

Remark 1.1.
Sorets-Spencer's result is nonperturbative: the
"largeness" condition  does not depend on .
On the other hand, the proof of Eliasson's result is
perturbative: the "smallness" condition
depends in principle on  (in the full measure set ).  We will come back to this issue (cf. Theorem ).

Remark 1.2.
In general, one cannot replace "almost every" by "every"
in Eliasson's result above.  Indeed, in it is also shown
that the set of energies for which
is not (even )
reducible is nonempty for a generic (in an appropriate topology)
choice of  satisfying .
Those "exceptional" energies do have zero Lyapunov exponent.

Remark 1.3.
Let  and , .
In this case,  is uniformly hyperbolic if and only if it is
-reducible and has a positive Lyapunov exponent, see.
Thus, there are lots of "simple cocycles" for which one has
positive Lyapunov exponent, resp. reducibility, and indeed both at the same
time: this is the case in particular for  large in the Schrodinger
case.  Those examples are also stable (here we fix  and
stability is with respect to perturbations of ).

However, cocycles with a positive Lyapunov exponent, resp. reducible,
but which are not uniformly hyperbolic do happen for a
positive measure set of energies
for many choices of the potential, and in particular in the situations
described by the results of Sorets-Spencer (this follows from
), resp. Eliasson.

However, cocycles with a positive Lyapunov exponent, resp. reducible,
but which are not uniformly hyperbolic do happen for a
positive measure set of energies
for many choices of the potential, and in particular in the situations
described by the results of Sorets-Spencer (this follows from
), resp. Eliasson.

Our main result for Schrodinger cocycles aims to close the gap and
describe the situation (for almost every energy) without
largeness/smallness assumption on the potential:

Theorem A. Let  and let  be a
potential. Then, for Lebesgue almost every , the cocycle
is either
nonuniformly hyperbolic or -reducible.
For , let

Given a -cocycle , we associate a canonical
one-parameter family of -cocycles .
Our proof of Theorem A goes through for the more general context of
cocycles homotopic to the identity, with the role of the energy parameter
replaced by the  parameter.

Theorem A.
Let , and let

6pt Remark 1.4.
Theorems A and A also hold in the smooth setting.  The only modification in
the proof is in the use of a KAM theoretical result of Eliasson
(see Theorem ), which must be replaced by a smooth
version.  They also generalize to the case of continuous time (differential
equations): in this case the adaptation is straightforward.  Seefor a discussion of those generalizations.

6pt Remark 1.4.
Theorems A and A also hold in the smooth setting.  The only modification in
the proof is in the use of a KAM theoretical result of Eliasson
(see Theorem ), which must be replaced by a smooth
version.  They also generalize to the case of continuous time (differential
equations): in this case the adaptation is straightforward.  Seefor a discussion of those generalizations.

6pt Remark 1.5.
One can distinguish two distinct behaviors among the
reducible cocycles  given by Theorems A and A.  The first
is uniformly hyperbolic behavior; see Remark 1.3.
The second is totally elliptic behavior, corresponding (projectively)
to an irrational rotation of .
More precisely, we call a cocycle totally elliptic if it is -reducible
and the constant matrix  in () can be chosen to be a
rotation , where  are linearly independent
over .  In this case it is easy to see that
the cocycle  is automatically -reducible modulo
(possibly replacing  by ).  (To see that
almost every reducible cocycle is either uniformly hyperbolic or totally
elliptic, it is enough to use Theorems  and  which
are due to Johnson-Moser and Deift-Simon.)
6pt

Theorems A and A give a nice global picture for the theory of
quasiperiodic cocycles, extending known results for cocycles taking values
on certain compact groups (see for the case of
).  They fit with the Palis conjecture for
general dynamical systems, and have a strong analogy with
the work of Lyubich in the quadratic family, generalized in
.

More importantly, reducible and nonuniformly
hyperbolic systems can be efficiently described through a wide variety of
methods, especially in the analytic case.  With respect to reducible
systems, the dynamics of the cocycle itself is of course very simple, and
the use of KAM theoretical methods (,) allowed
also a good comprehension of their perturbations.  With respect to
nonuniformly hyperbolic systems, there has
been recently lots of success in the application of
subtle properties of subharmonic functions (,,
) to obtain large deviation estimates with important consequences
(such as regularity properties of the Lyapunov exponent).

More importantly, reducible and nonuniformly
hyperbolic systems can be efficiently described through a wide variety of
methods, especially in the analytic case.  With respect to reducible
systems, the dynamics of the cocycle itself is of course very simple, and
the use of KAM theoretical methods (,) allowed
also a good comprehension of their perturbations.  With respect to
nonuniformly hyperbolic systems, there has
been recently lots of success in the application of
subtle properties of subharmonic functions (,,
) to obtain large deviation estimates with important consequences
(such as regularity properties of the Lyapunov exponent).

One way to interpret  (using the
Ishii-Pastur Theorem) is that generalized
eigenfunctions in the essential support of the absolutely continuous
spectrum are (very regular) Bloch waves.  This already
gives (in the particular cases under consideration) strong
versions of some conjectures in the literature (see for instance the
discussion after Theorem 7.1 in).  (Analogous statements
hold in the continuous time case.)

Another immediate application of Theorem A is a nonperturbative version of
Eliasson's result stated in Proposition 1.2.  It is based on the
following nonperturbative result:

There are several other interesting results which can be concluded easily
from Theorem A and current results and techniques:

(1)
Zero Lebesgue measure of  for almost every frequency,
(2) Persistence of absolutely continuous spectrum
under perturbations of the potential,
(3) Continuity of the Lebesgue measure of  under perturbations of
the potential.

Although the key ideas behind those results are quite
transparent (given the appropriate background), a proper
treatment would take us too far from the proof of Theorem A, which is the
main goal of this paper.  We will thus concentrate on a particular case
which provides one of the most striking applications of Theorem A.  For the
applications mentioned above (and others), see.

Almost Mathieu
Certainly the most studied family of potentials
in the literature is , .
In this case,  is called the Almost Mathieu Operator.

Almost Mathieu
Certainly the most studied family of potentials
in the literature is , .
In this case,  is called the Almost Mathieu Operator.

The Aubry-Andre conjecture on the measure of the spectrum of the Almost
Mathieu Operator states that the measure of the spectrum of  is  for every
,  (see).The "critical case"  can be traced even further

There is a long story of
developments around this problem, which led to several partial results
(,,,).

for every  (see), and for every  not of

should prove zero Lebesgue measure of the spectrum,
previous to this work, it was  still unknown even whether the spectrum has empty interior.

Outline of the proof of Theorem A
The proof has some distinct steps, and is based on a renormalization scheme.
This point of view, which has already been used  in the study of
reducibility properties of quasiperiodic cocycles with values in
and , has proved to be very useful in the nonperturbative case
(see,).  However, the scheme we present in this paper
is somehow simpler and fits better (at least in the  case)
with the general renormalization philosophy (see  for a very nice
description of this point of view on renormalization):

The starting point is the theory of Kotani(This step holds in
much greater generality, namely for cocycles over ergodic transformations.).
For almost every energy , if the Lyapunov exponent of
is zero, then the cocycle is -conjugate to a cocycle in
.  Moreover, the fibered rotation number of the cocycle

is Diophantine with respect to .  (The set  of those
energies will be precisely the set of energies for which we will be able to
conclude reducibility.)

is Diophantine with respect to .  (The set  of those
energies will be precisely the set of energies for which we will be able to
conclude reducibility.)

We now consider a smooth
cocycle  which is -conjugate to rotations.  An
explicit estimate allows us to control the derivatives of iterates of the
cocycle restricted to certain small intervals.

After introducing the notion of renormalization of cocycles,
we interpret item (2) as "a priori bounds" (or precompactness)
for a sequence of renormalizations .

The recurrent Diophantine condition for  allows us
to take  uniformly
Diophantine, so that the limits of renormalization are
cocycles  where  satisfies a
Diophantine condition.  Those limits are essentially (that is, modulo a
constant conjugacy) cocycles in ,
and are trivial to analyze: they are always reducible.

Since  is reducible, Eliasson's theorem
allows us to conclude that some renormalization
must be reducible, provided the
fibered rotation number of
is Diophantine with respect to .

This last condition is actually equivalent to the fibered rotation
number of  being Diophantine with respect to .
It is easy to see that reducibility is invariant under
renormalization and  so  is itself reducible.

We conclude that for almost every  such that
, the cocycle  is reducible, which
is equivalent to Theorem A by Remark 1.3.

The above strategy uses  in order to take
good limits of renormalization.  It would be interesting to try to obtain
results under the weaker condition  by working directly with
deep renormalizations (without considering limits).

The above strategy uses  in order to take
good limits of renormalization.  It would be interesting to try to obtain
results under the weaker condition  by working directly with
deep renormalizations (without considering limits).

Renormalization methods have been previously applied to the study of
quasiperiodic Schrodinger operators, see for instance,
and.  While the
notions used by Helffer-Sjostrand are quite different from ours, the
"monodromization techniques" of Buslaev-Fedotov-Klopp
correspond to essentially the
same notion of renormalization used here.  An important conceptual
difference is in the use of renormalization: we are interested in the
dynamics of the renormalization operator itself, in a spirit close to
works in
one-dimensional dynamics (see for instance,,
).

Both theorems above are valid in a much more general setting, namely for
cocycles over transformations preserving a probability measure.  The
requirement on the cocycle is the least  to speak of Lyapunov exponents
(and Oseledets theory), namely integrability of the logarithm of the norm.

Fibered rotation number
Besides the Lyapunov exponent, there is one important invariant
associated to continuous cocycles which are
homotopic to the identity.  This invariant, called the fibered rotation
number will be denoted by , and
was introduced in, (we recall its definition in
Appendix A).
The fibered rotation number is a continuous function of
, where  varies in the space of continuous cocycles
which are homotopic to the identity.  Another important elementary
fact is that both  and  have nondecreasing lifts , and in
particular, those functions have nonnegative derivatives almost everywhere.
The following result was proved in, in the continuous time case,
and in, in the discrete time case used here
(and where an optimal estimate is given).

Let .  Then for almost every  such that
,

for further generalizations):

Let  be continuous and homotopic to the
identity.  Then for almost every  such that
,

In the Schrodinger case, it is possible to show that the fibered rotation
number is a surjective function (of ) onto .  In it
is also shown that  can be interpreted as
the integrated density of states.

The arithmetic properties of the fibered rotation number are also important
for the analysis of cocycles .

Reducibility
An action  is called constant if for every ,
is constant.
We will say that an action
is -reducible if it is -conjugate to a constant action.
It immediately follows that reducibility is invariant
under conjugation, translation, rescaling and base change.  Thus
reducibility is also invariant under renormalization: an action
is-reducible
